posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content:
Why not use one-handed: Morningstar: Bludgeoning and piercing damage. Two-handed: Scythe/halberd: Slashing and Piercing. You can get all three damage types with just two weapons. That would also seem more logical for a Weaponmaster, to use one "big" weapon and one "medium+shield-combo". Also, it would make the build much easier to set up.

I know, it's not Zaknafein if you don't have those specific weapons, but still.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Love it, Aquarius! It's a sort of (Mick's) Epic Brawler Champion for elves. On first look, just two or three things, if you don't mind...

First, drop Fighter to 8 and raise CoT to 10. CoT can take EWS (though not WS). That will bump your saves by 1 (not that they're rubbish anyway) and you lose nothing. You also gain something else at CoT10, but it's CHA-related so won't really impact here.

Second, take your first WS at Fighter level 4. Hit the weaklings early and hard. You can take both Spring Attack and Whirlwind at level 6.

Third, and this is more a personal take - though I understand why you would do it this way, and given the restrictions of WM - I'm not keen on Epic Fort and Epic Toughness at 39 and 40. Maybe another couple of Fighter levels (brought back later) could give you that E/WS in mace you were after?

I'm going to try this one!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
R. A. Salvatore
The Dark Elf Trilogy => https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Dark_Elf_Trilogy

It still reads quite nicely even after all these years, and frankly, any Dungeons & Dragons fun should read these books alongside Dragonlance.

“Catch them all, Secondboy.” he said in all seriousness. “Catch them all, or you will land in
Sorcere, the school of magic. That is not where you belong!”

Drizzt still had only a vague idea of what Zak was talking about, but he could tell from the
weapon master’s intensity that it must be important. He took a deep breath to steady himself, then
snapped the coins up. He sorted their glow quickly, discerning each individual item. The first two
fell easily into his hands, but Drizzt saw that the scattering pattern of the rest would not drop them
so readily in line.

Drizzt exploded into action, spinning a complete circle, his hands an indecipherable blur of
motion. Then he straightened suddenly and stood before Zak. His hands were in fists at his sides
and a grim look lay on his face.
Zak and Matron Malice exchanged glances, neither quite sure of what had happened.
Drizzt held his fists out to Zak and slowly opened them, a confident smile widening across his
childish face. Five coins in each hand.

Zak blew a silent whistle. It had taken him, the weapon master of the house, a dozen tries to
complete that maneuver with ten coins. He walked over to Matron Malice.
“Two-hands,” he said a third time. “He is a fighter, and I am out of coins.”
“How many could he do?” Malice breathed, obviously impressed in spite of herself.
“How many could we stack?” Zaknafein shot back with a triumphant smile.
Matron Malice chuckled out loud and shook her head. She had wanted Drizzt to replace
Nalfein as the house wizard, but her stubborn weapon master had, as always, deflected her course.
“Very well, Zaknafein.” she said, admitting her defeat. “The secondboy is a fighter.”
Zak nodded and started back to Drizzt.

“Perhaps one day soon to be the weapon master of House Do’Urden.” Matron Malice added
to Zak’s back. Her sarcasm stopped Zak short, and he eyed her over his shoulder.
“With this one.” Matron Malice continued wryly, wrenching back the upper hand with her
usual lack of shame, “could we expect anything less?”
Rizzen, the present patron of the family shifted uncomfortably. He knew, and so did everyone
―even the slaves of House Do’Urden―that Drizzt was not his child.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Far be it from me to critique Mick's work, but if I may offer a few comments on an exciting build...

Scimitar appears to be lost in epic levels, which seems a shame. IKD could go for EWF:Scimitar, at least.

However, and this might be missing the spirit of the thing, but with just 2 WoCs - Scimitar and Morning Star (which iirc is both blunt and piercing), you can cover all 3 attack types. This would free up some feats for things like Blind Fighting and Imp Crit - or even some dual-wielding (I know you can't d-w Flail, but I think you can Morning Star).

And, again, is there something badly wrong with having 10 levels of CoT? Either with 22 WM and 8 Fighter, or 20 WM and retaining 10 Fighter?

Anyway, just a few thoughts...

Cheers

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Stag, this is a crazy build concept, based more on a fictional character than practical NWN play. And my build is by no means "polished". It only serves to demonstrate that you can build with 3 WoCs. And you are right about Morningstar (my favourite simple weapon that is better than it's martial counterpart, the light flail.) I would not dual wield it though.
As for 10 CoT levels: It might work and give better saves in more than one way. (more CoT and better pre epic class spread saves wise)
You need 6 fighter levels to qualify for WM. You then need at least 2 more fighter levels for the 2 remaining WSs.
If you take F8 CoT2 pre epic you get one more pre epic feat and one less epic feats compared with F9 CoT1.This means that you can move IKD to pre epic. 
The epic feats will be delayed some but the build should work fine.

Edit: I don't quite understand what you mean by "scimitars lost in epic levels" so it is hard for me to comment on that.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks, Mick. I like crazy build concepts! It's all about enjoyment, after all. And I'm pleased to see another Morningstar fan - flashy variants (sorry, enhanced versions) of the weapon are sadly under-used by most game designers.

My point about Scimitar was that you don't take EWF or EWS in it - unlike Rapier and Morningstar. Sorry if I was unclear. That formed part of my thinking about maybe dropping WM to 20 and having both Fighter and CoT at 10 (so you'd lose IKD but be able to take both EWF and EWS in Scimitar with that one extra feat).

Cheers

Second: certainly for me, it's simply a question of priorities. If I've got room after taking "mandatory" feats as a meleer - WF/ BF/ KD/ Imp Crit - then "would like to have" ones, like IKD/ Dodge/ Expertise - and anything you might need for secondary classes, then things like Iron Will (which I'd personally whack right up there, because I hate failing a Will throw as a meleer) and so on would be the next port of call. As for me, I have not read the novels you refer to. (Probably shoud though). So, I'm sorry, it is hard to target the charater concept precicely. But I have to admit I had fun building an "over the top" weaponmaster.
Just a quick question: why do in many builds you (almost always) tend to avoid the "Epic/non-epic saves" feats (except for luck of heroes when human)?
I sometimes use the saves feat extensively. Take a look at my thread "The Kukrimaster revisited" or my take on Minsc in the "Minsc and other BG characters" thread here in this build request forum. I am especially fond of boosting the fort saves in builds made for Dev crit environments. But sometimes I also try to make builds with a fortified will save to compensate for the low will saves of fighter/rogue builds. In general I try to use CoT in builds where I want good saves. I also look at the level spread at 20 and try to give every class the number of levels that give the best saves combination if feasible.

I sometimes use the saves feat extensively. Take a look at my thread "The Kukrimaster revisited" or my take on Minsc in the "Minsc and other BG characters" thread here in this build request forum. I am especially fond of boosting the fort saves in builds made for Dev crit environments. But sometimes I also try to make builds with a fortified will save to compensate for the low will saves of fighter/rogue builds. In general I try to use CoT in builds where I want good saves. I also look at the level spread at 20 and try to give every class the number of levels that give the best saves combination if feasible.
Not a problem Mick, I am just a little disappointed as I truly believed that a Zak build was viable, however I understand that "you cannot have everything" and I truly thank you all for your suggestions: I think l will have a good time playing your proposed build ("Musashi"/"Elf weapon master with specialization in two/three weapons"/elf WM dual-wielding longswords), and I will surely take a look to the "Minsc" post and treasure your opinions and notes. 

Edit: if someone wants to make suggestions, feel free to post ;)

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
In my experience so far, you can almost have everything in a build - but not in the way that most of you think when you read this,
You see, there are types of builds out there that do not have a weak point - at all, I will name just one but you get the point, Ftr/Rog/CoT,
That type of build has strong AB (if you build it correctly), average AC, very strong saves (depending on how much CoT you put into this), loads of feats, etc.
What it doesn't have is any kind of explosive power, it doesn't have the humongous strength of a dragon, the jaw-dropping AB of a weapon-master OR the raw magical power of a sorceress,
What it does have is consistency.
So, in essence, you CAN have almost everything, as long as you don't also ask for the sky itself ;)

Specialized builds that offer some very strong points will always have some things that are mediocre at, even after all these years that we have them optimized again & again...
Case in point, "Musashi-Zaknafein" build even though he has everything from combat feats, he still has mediocre (at best) saving throws.
And I guess it would also be boring if we could do anything with a single build, right?

Edit: Stag, some old-school pen & paper drawing of a build can be incredibly relaxing & rewarding as well, this is how Tracy Hickman designed Dragonlance in the first place after all (in a traffic jam, on some tissue paper).
So take your pencil once again & give it a try ;)

Have fun.
